Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2013 07:01PM Jo6202 wrote: Babs, great news! Wrenn, glad you are able to finally start chemo. Ditto what Babs said about you being there for the rest of us and now it's your turn. Best of luck to you. Keep us updated when you are feeling up to it. I don't post every day but I do keep up reading daily. One quick story about calling MO. My son who went through chemo was told to call if ANY question. Well he wouldn't call when he got a red and itchy eye so I did and was I in trouble for doing so! He had to have MO appt. next day and he was put on antibiotics immediately because he had an eye infection. MO said if he had let it go with no immunity he could have been in really big trouble. Moral of story....call about any concern while doing chemo.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2013 04:59PM Jo6202 wrote: Lili and VintageGal, I looked pretty good after my lumpectomy but then didn't get clear margins so had second surgery and still looked ok but then realized I had a Seroma the size of my hand. Once the swelling and Seroma went away ....ugly puckering and realized a quarter of my breast was gone. I do not have a PS yet because RO said my breast may shrink from the radiation. Once everything is done and everything has settled to where it is going to be then will see what a PS can do for me. I was a dd so have extra they could use from my good girl. Lili when I talked with surgeon she thought a lumpectomy was very doable but once she got to my tumor against my chest wall she found a second tumor right next to it that had to come out. It never showed on mammogram or US. Then the re-excision took even more tissue out. I guess at the initial consultation she just had no idea that I have always been a challenging patient. My PCP calls me her mystery patient and she says you never want to be a mystery patient! Every surgery I have ever had has had unexpected surprises. I won't bore you with undiagnosed illnesses, pregnancies, etc but I never have common symptoms. My bc tumor showed on mammograms for past three years but did not look like cancer to radiologists. Never felt a lump but breast started having indentation because tumor was pulling on tissue on the other side of the breast so had biopsy on area that did not appear to be anything on mammogram. Then surprise the big "C".

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2014 08:19PM Jo6202 wrote: Lili, Got a form letter in the mail today (Saturday) ..says there is an area that is (in bold type) "probably benign" and a copy is being sent to my doctor. " someone will be calling from scheduling to set you up for another follow up mammo in  6 months to see if there are any changes".  Are they kidding me?  They did not mention which breast. My cancer showed on my mammos for three years and they thought it was nothing. Do they think I would believe them ever again about "probably benign"?  I thought I was going to throw up when I read the letter and being the weekend I just have to sit and stew. Lisa, Thanks for asking. I don't want to tell any family or friends and upset them so as always it feels good to be able to vent here.

If she doesn't get a clear margin in this spot this time then I will need a mastectomy. I have not met my RO yet so everything is subject to change depending on his opinion. Katlebbie, thanks for your kind words. I like your avatar, you have a little cutie there. School counselor, sounds like you have wonderful co-workers. Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2013 05:32PM Jo6202 wrote: Hi Dawn, Just a word of encouragement. I just had a re-excision on Sept 11th. The doctor went through my original incision and took additional tissue but she knew right where she needed to go and so she did not have to disturb the surrounding tissue that was already healing. So glad she did go back because they found additional cancer cells and now I have clear margins going forward. I do have to wait three more weeks before I can start radiation. I do believe waiting is the name of the game here! :-) I will be thinking of you.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2013 08:42PM Jo6202 wrote: sandymomto3- yes I'm having the Oncotype DX test. I was the same as you wanted the breast conserving surgery and was a good candidate. I did not get clear margins so had second surgery Sept 11th. Then didn't like first MO who wouldn't give me copy of pathology report so wrote down what he was showing me and he said I didn't need to do that. Always had to wait at least two hours to see him and then he said my anemia was better by .2 but platelets down by.2 end of meeting. This was my first consult for bc with him. I had been seeing him for anemia prior to bc diagnosis. Never had blood pressure taken, weight check, never had an exam of any kind. Always met in his office. So I called and cancelled next appt. and said I wouldn't be back. Just starting with new female MO. I was so impressed with first meeting. Physical exam, all vitals checked, complete medical history of me and family gone through. Checked my Seroma, surgical scars, every little bump or bruise. She couldn't believe I have been anemic for three years so complete set of blood work done right on the spot. She is also a hematologist. She then ordered the oncotype test. She said to go ahead and do the simulation for radiation but then we need to wait until all the tests come back but I will be ready to go on with radiation if Oncotype and several other tests come back ok. The oncotype test should be back on Oct. 24th. July 2nd was my first visit about a change in my breast so to me this just has been so trying....I hate all this waiting.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2013 03:37AM Jo6202 wrote: Hi everyone, I had a lumpectomy on Friday. The good news was clear lymph nodes. The bad news is the margins are not clear. I go to see the surgeon this Friday. Not looking forward to more surgery and more waiting. I lost it at my primary care doctor's office when she said things seem to be going quickly for me. It has been two months of mental torture. So dr says she can give me meds for anxiety...don't want more meds just answers and a plan of action. Scouser47, No I didn't try the bras yet but hope to stop and get one after my appointment today. Liefie, thanks for the feel better words. I was scheduled for a lumpectomy and thought they would check for clear margins up to two times while I was still in the operating room. I was totally surprised to find out that I was closed up and had to wait 7 days to find out if the margins were clear. They are not clear so I meet with the surgeon today to discuss what to do now. It is currently 4 in the morning and I can't sleep because I'm thinking just go for the mastectomy and get done with it. Thinking of Dakota , Jackie and Trail. How are you doing? Nihahi, beautiful pictures. I live in Michigan but am an Arizona snowbird and I do miss the mountains. Hope I get to see them this year. I may be stuck here in the snow for the first time in many years if we don't get my treatment show on the road. Carlads, I am changing oncologist also. The first one said his printer was not working when I asked for a copy of my stereotactic biopsy. So I started to write down what I could see on his computer screen and he asked me what I was doing. I told him writing down the information and he said I didn't need to be doing that. RED FLAG warnings going off in my head!
Posts.Title: In shock bennymuffins websister

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2013 07:26PM Jo6202 wrote: Liefie, I hate when I feel I overpay for anything. I always think what else I could have bought for the money. Glad the blanket turned out well.
Posts.Title: In shock bennymuffins websister

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2013 02:59AM Jo6202 wrote: Michele, sorry you have to join our club. It is ok to cry. It is ok to get angry. I go through streaks of crying then fine for weeks then tears are back. It is a roller coaster ride for sure but you can do it. My doctor told me right at the first meeting that if my tests came back Her2+ that I would need chemo. Didn't know what the heck she meant! I think we are bombarded with so much information while we are still in shock that we just can't process it all. I had my hubby with me and he understood some things that I just didn't and vice versa. Do you have a friend or relative to go with you to your appointments to be a second set of ears? Just remember, this is not a death sentence. I have two sons who have been through cancer and two sister-in-laws who had breast cancer. All are doing very well and all have been through chemo and radiation. I also have two miracle grand kids ...my son was told he would not be able to have children after his chemo. We can do this together.

Then I had valley fever for two years. We joke about our golden years being filled with doctor appointments. We both retired with hundreds of sick leave days each and now seems like all we do is go to appointments. My sisters and I took care of my dad after a stroke and that was a lot of work for three years. Hope you are recovered from that health issue. I can't imagine dealing with both a stroke and cancer. You sure have a positive outlook for all you have been through. You are an inspiration!

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2013 11:06AM Jo6202 wrote: Hi Dawn, Glad your surgeon was able to make you feel better about the re-excision. I am also a DD sister and have also always wanted a reduction. I do have a concern about this and maybe someone out there can help both of us with an answer. My SIL had bc and went through radiation and her breast shrunk by two sizes. She had a reduction in the healthy breast then to match in size the radiated breast. My SIL is not happy with the reduction in her healthy breast because she still does not match in size although closer than two sizes difference. Her plastic surgeon told her "this is not an exact science". Would it be best to wait until after radiation to see if there are changes in size? Has anyone else had a reduction before or after radiation?

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2013 04:52PM Jo6202 wrote: cjc1961-I am going to an ONC with 29 years experience and I have similar diagnosis as you. 1.74 cm tumor, oncotype DX 12. I chose lumpectomy. ONC said oncotype score would determine if she would recommend chemo because I was in a "gray" area as far as tumor size. When test came back at 12 she said no chemo needed. I am doing 33 days of rads because I chose the lumpectomy. A second opinion is a good idea. Best of luck in your decision.
